clinical_study.brief_title: Macintosh Blade Size During Laryngoscopy for Endotracheal Intubation. A Prospective Observational Study.
clinical_study.official_title: Macintosh Blade Size During Laryngoscopy for Endotracheal Intubation. A Prospective Observational Study.

brief_summary.textblock: Endotracheal intubation is a frequent procedure in the operating room, in intensive care units and in emergency medicine (in- or out-of-hospital) but optimal Macintosh blade size remains unknown to date.

detailed_description.textblock: Endotracheal intubation is an extremely frequent procedure in the operating room, in intensive care units and in emergency medicine (in- or out-of-hospital). Apart from special cases of foreseen difficult programmed intubation, direct laryngoscopy remains the most frequently used technique. It requires the use of a handle (short or long), which serves as a light source on which is adapted a Macintosh curved blade, metallic or plastic, single or multiple use. The choice of blade size is based on the experience of the physician. Most often, in adult settings, size 3 or 4 blades are used. The very spartan literature on the subject and the current recommendations do not provide any information on the choice of blade size. We therefore wish to evaluate these practices in terms of success of the first laryngoscopy, Cormack-Lehane and POGO (percentage of glottic opening visualized) scores, the need to use an alternative technique or a second operator. The results will be analyzed with regard as a function and experience of the person performing the laryngoscopy, as well as the setting (urgent or scheduled). These data are usually collected during the performance of an endotracheal intubation whatever the circumstances: operating room, intensive care unit and emergency department (in-hospital) and in the SAMU-SMUR (pre-hospiatl medical service) at Clermont-Ferrand University Hospital.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with successful first-pass orotracheal intubation
primary_outcome.description: The proportion of patients with successful first-pass orotracheal intubation

secondary_outcome.description: Rate of severe hypoxemia defined by lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) < 80 %

secondary_outcome.measure: Severe complications related to intubation_severe collapse
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of cardiovascular collapse, defined as systolic blood pressure less than 65 mm Hg recorded at least once or less than 90 mm Hg lasting 30 minutes despite 500-1,000 ml of fluid loading (crystalloids solutions) or requiring introduction or increasing doses by more than 30% of vasoactive support

secondary_outcome.measure: Severe complications related to intubation_cardiac arrest
Moderate complications related to intubation_difficult intubation

secondary_outcome.description: Rate of severe ventricular or supraventricular arrhythmia requiring intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Moderate complications related to intubation_oesophageal intubation
Moderate complications related to intubation_dental injuries

secondary_outcome.description: Rate of Cormack-Lehane grade of glottic view
Rate of operator-assessed difficulty of intubation
Rate of need for additional airway equipment (video laryngoscope, bougie, stylet, fibroscope, cricothyrotomy)
Rate of need for a second operator
Rate of POGO grade of glottic view

arm_group.description: Patients intubated using Macintosh blade size 3
Patients intubated using Macintosh blade size 4

intervention.description: Patients in operative room, intensive care unit and emergency department requiring direct laryngoscopy for endotracheal intubation

study_pop.textblock: Any patient requiring orotracheal intubation with direct laryngoscopy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients must be admitted in an operative room, an intensive care unit (ICU) or an emergency department and require mechanical ventilation through an orotracheal tube.
- Adult (age â‰¥ 18 years)
- Subjects must be covered by public health insurance
- Written informed consent from the patient or proxy (if present) before inclusion or once possible when patient has been included in a context of emergency.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Anticipated difficult intubation requiring videolaryngoscopy
- Nasotracheal intubation
- Refusal of study participation or to pursue the study by the patient
- Absence of coverage by the French statutory healthcare insurance system
- Protected person
